awd_titl_txt: Upgrading plant-functional-types with plant trait variability in ecohydrological models: A stochastic parameterization approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Ecohydrological models that incorporate carbon and water cycles can predict related changes in vegetation growth and soil water reservoirs in response to climate and land-use perturbations.  They are thus critical for helping us prepare for ecosystem and water resource vulnerabilities.  Such models also play an important role in determining feedbacks from vegetation and soils that can accelerate or slow climate change.  However, much of the uncertainty in these models arises because of how they currently represent plants.  These models simplify the enormous diversity of plants into a tractable number of ?plant-functional-types? (PFTs), each of which have uniform, fixed sets of parameters applied to them.  Although PFTs group together related species with similar characteristics, recently compiled global plant data reveal that certain plant traits can vary just as much within these pre-specified PFT groups as between distinct groups.  Because these plant properties can affect plant uptake of water and CO2, this study will incorporate plant trait variability into ecohydrological models in order to improve future predictions about our changing ecosystems, water resources, and climate. 
	The current paradigm of fixed-parameter PFTs in ecohydrological models needs upgrading to align with new findings in ecology on plant trait variability.  The proposed work offers a new stochastic approach that simulates plant trait plasticity; these are adaptations that occur over time and space in response to complex environmental drivers and give rise to variability within PFTs.  A spatiotemporally stochastic PFT parameterization will be developed based on global plant trait data that capture distributions of intra-PFT variability.  Importantly, the parameterization will be further conditioned on spatiotemporal biotic and abiotic data to fill gaps in the plant trait datasets and rigorously account for uncertainties in applying sparse global data to these models.  This approach marks a novel departure from recent modeling efforts that incorporate trait variability as random parameters fixed in space and time or as deterministic inputs that fail to address uncertainties.  The stochastic PFT parameterization will be first developed for a desert shrubland setting, which critically needs a new model representation that can capture temperature and moisture acclimation by its plants.  Simulations with the new model will reveal relationships in desert shrublands between plant traits and environmental variables such as climate and soil type.  Plant trait variability is ubiquitous among all PFTs; the stochastic parameterization approach generated in this study will thus benefit ecohydrological modeling globally.

por.por_cntn:
Ecohydrological models that capture water flow and vegetation dynamics are essential for understanding and predicting the response of water and carbon cycles to changes in climate and land use/land cover. However, models often include simplified representations of vegetation, which adds significant uncertainty to their results. Our work addressed this by incorporating spatially and temporally variable plant parameters into models in order to more realistically represent key plant traits that control the function of vegetation in mediating water and carbon fluxes. We leveraged the growing availability of variable plant trait observations made possible through remote sensing and global field data compilations. However, their coverage is still not exhaustive or sufficiently detailed, prompting us to also develop a new data-conditioned stochastic parameterization framework that builds off sparse and/or related measurements to estimate unobserved plant trait variability. A key strength of the framework is its ability to provide inferences of temporal trait variability, for which there are far less data and fewer studies than for spatial trait variability.

We investigated the role of variable plant traits in three different critical environments to evaluate their importance across climatic zones: the Mojave Desert, where climate change will exacerbate already harsh growing conditions; Amazonian evergreen forests, which play a major role in global carbon budgets; and the Upper Great Lakes region, which is projected to undergo some of the fastest rates of warming in the U.S. Through application of our stochastic parameterization framework in the Mojave Desert, we identified leaf trait responses to dynamic soil water limitations that allow desert plants to function with greater water-use efficiency. Under future climate scenarios, we found that this efficiency can help plants buffer against water stresses under moderate warming projections, but the trait responses will not likely be able to keep apace with more pessimistic warming projections. In Amazonian evergreen forests, our stochastic parameterization also constrained estimates of plant trait variability, but this time in response to radiation availability. Accounting for this radiation-dependent trait variability led to predictions of at least a third of the radiation-limited portions of the Amazonion evergreen forests serving as a future net carbon sink ? contrary to simulations using conventional static plant trait parameters. In the Upper Great Lakes region, we found that groundwater recharge is highly sensitive to leaf phenological responses to variable springtime temperatures, and that other land-surface processes such as soil moisture limitations and frozen ground dynamics will further modulate how future climate change will impact recharge. Also in the Upper Great Lakes regions, our model scenario tests showed that leaf trait changes that accompany potential warming-induced forest cover shifts may cause larger impacts on springtime runoff than direct effects from changes in climate variables. 

Our study provides modeling tools and frameworks that we have shown will provide more reliable predictions of water and carbon fluxes across climate zones. These are needed to inform water and ecological resource management and climate change resilience plans. In particular for our work in Upper Great Lakes region, collaboration with Minnesota state agencies and tribal environmental divisions ensured that our investigations addressed practitioner needs and that results were communicated back in a useful way.
